('Out of pocket', '自費'): He bought it out of pocket.
('Got cheated on', '被劈腿了'): He got cheated on last night.
('Keep an eye on', '顧個東西的「顧」'): Keep an eye on my bag
Keep an eye on the kids.
('烏鴉嘴',): Every time he speaks, he jinxes everything
每次他一說話就會招來厄運
Don't even say that, you'll jinx our luck
別那樣說，你會把我們的運氣弄壞
We think he's a jinx because his tips always backfire
我們覺得他是個衰神，因為他的建議總是適得其反
Stop being a jinx and say something positive for once
別再當衰神了，這次說點正面的話吧
(\"I'll give you that.\",): I'll give you that, you made a good point about the budget
那點我承認，你關於預算的說法很有道理
I'll give you that, the movie was visually stunning despite the slow plot
那點我承認，雖然劇情緩慢，但電影畫面很驚豔
I'll give you that, she handled the crisis better than anyone else in the office
那點我承認，她處理危機比辦公室裡其他人都好
I'll give you that, but we still need concrete data before making the final decision
那點我承認，但我們在做最終決定前仍需要具體數據
(\"That's a given\",): He's worked hard, so that's a given
他一直很努力，所以那是理所當然的
When the boss says yes, that's a given
當老闆說同意，那是理所當然的
With their experience, a win here? That's a given
憑他們的經驗，要贏這場比賽？那是理所當然的
Skip practice for months, then expect results? That's a given
幾個月都沒練，還想有成果？那是理所當然的
('Savage',): He gave a savage attack on the intruder
他對入侵者發動了殘酷的攻擊
The critic's review was savage and brutally honest
那位評論家的評論既殘酷又直言不諱
That movie's violence felt savage and unnecessary for the plot
那部電影的暴力看起來殘暴且對劇情毫無必要
They launched a savage campaign that left the town devastated and terrified
他們發起了一場殘酷的行動，讓整個城鎮陷入毀滅與驚恐
(\"twist one's arm\",): She twisted his arm to join the team
她勉強說服他加入球隊
I didn't have to twist his arm at all
If you twist my arm I'll help out this weekend
如果你逼我，我這個週末會幫忙
They had to twist her arm before she agreed to the interview
他們得勉強說服她，她才同意接受訪問
('Learn the ropes',): It takes time to learn the ropes at work
在工作上熟悉流程需要時間
New hires need weeks to learn the ropes properly
新進員工需要好幾週才能真正熟悉流程
If you shadow a mentor, you'll learn the ropes much faster
跟著導師學，你會更快熟悉流程
Take notes during training and you'll learn the ropes sooner than expected
培訓時做筆記，你會比預期更快學會要領
(\"Don't put yourself out\",): Don't put yourself out for them, you deserve rest
別為他們勉強自己，你值得休息
If they're fine, don't put yourself out trying to help
如果他們沒事，就別為了幫忙勉強自己
Don't put yourself out to impress others; your health comes first
別為了給別人留下印象而勉強自己；你的健康最重要
When work piles up, don't put yourself out—set limits and ask for help
工作堆積時別逼自己——要設界限並尋求幫助
('Sassy',): That sassy remark made everyone laugh out loud
那句俏皮的話讓大家笑出聲
He gave a sassy wink and walked away
他俏皮地眨了眨眼就走了
Her sassy attitude wins fans, but sometimes gets her into trouble
她的俏皮態度贏得粉絲，但有時也會惹麻煩
I love your sassy comebacks they're witty and unexpected
我喜歡你那些俏皮的回嘴，既機智又出人意料
('I have a thing for you',): I've got a thing for you
Honestly, I have a thing for you, not joking
說真的，我對你有好感，不是在開玩笑
I have a thing for you, and I can't hide it
我對你有好感，無法隱藏
I have a thing for you since college, I've liked you for years
從大學起我就對你有好感，我已喜歡你好多年
Even when you're annoying, I have a thing for you, it's true
即使你有點煩，我還是對你有好感，這是真的
('Make a scene',): She threatened to make a scene at dinner
她威脅在晚餐時大吵大鬧
If you make a scene now, we'll leave
如果你現在大吵大鬧，我們就走
He always makes a scene when criticized in public
他一被當眾批評就總是大吵大鬧
Don't encourage her to make a scene; calm her down instead
別鼓勵她大吵大鬧；要安撫她
('Hand to god',): Hand to God, I'm telling the truth
我向上帝發誓我說的是真的
Hand to God, she was here last night
我向上帝發誓她昨晚在這裡
Hand to God, he said he paid the money
我向上帝發誓他說他已經付過錢
Hand to God, I would never betray your trust
我向上帝發誓我絕不會背叛你的信任
Hand to God, ask anyone — they'll tell you I helped
我向上帝發誓，你去問任何人，他們會說我有幫忙
('take it in stride',): Just take it in stride and move on
就從容面對，然後繼續前進
When things go wrong, try to take it in stride
事情出錯時，試著從容應對
He always takes setbacks in stride and rarely loses his cool
他總是從容面對挫折，很少失去冷靜
If you can take it in stride now, you'll handle worse challenges later with confidence
如果你現在能從容面對，將來就能自信地應對更嚴峻的挑戰
('Beats me',): Beats me, I haven't checked the schedule yet
我不知道，我還沒看行程表
Beats me, maybe ask Sarah—she might know
我不知道，也許問莎拉，她可能知道
Honestly, beats me when it comes to taxes and legal stuff
坦白說，遇到稅務和法律方面的事我就不懂
Beats me how they fixed the server so quickly without telling anyone
我不懂他們怎麼沒告訴任何人就這麼快修好伺服器
(\"pull one's leg\",): I thought he was serious but he was pulling my leg
我以為他是認真的，但他只是在耍我
She loves to pull my leg about my terrible cooking
她喜歡拿我糟糕的廚藝開玩笑
When they said I won a million dollars I knew they were pulling my leg
當他們說我贏了一百萬時，我就知道他們在耍我
He can be so sarcastic that sometimes it's hard to tell if he's pulling your leg or being sincere
他常常那麼諷刺，有時很難分辨他是在耍你還是很真心
('have someone going',): 那個惡作劇把我騙到了
She had everyone going with that fake story
她用那個假故事把大家都騙了
Don't try to have me going again
He managed to have the whole office going for hours
他讓整個辦公室好幾個小時都上當了
By pretending to be the CEO, she had investors going for weeks
她冒充執行長，讓投資者好幾個星期都上當了
(\"You're way off\",): You're way off if you think that's right
如果你認為那是對的，那你就大錯特錯了
You're way off about the timeline they gave
你對他們給的時間表估計完全錯了
I hate to tell you this, but you're way off about the project's budget
我很不想說，但你對專案預算的估計完全錯了
When it comes to predicting weather, you're way off more often than not
說到預測天氣，你經常大錯特錯
